Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructorâ€™s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: What is the difference between List Matrix and Data Frame
Input.posts:
List, Matrix and Data frame all look similar structurally. They have dimension and can include different class of objects. So when to use which?
Upvotes:
1
A list is a one dimensional structure. The difference between a list and a vector is that the list may contain elements of different classes, whereas in a normal vector they must be the same. The list is usually indexed with the names of the elements, or alternatively with integers. A matrix is a two- or more dimensional structure: columns and rows. I think it is mostly used for numerical calculations like in linear algebra, but I think it can also be used for general data storage. A data.frame is also two dimensional, but it is used for statistical data that belongs together, like different measurements of the same items. Each column is a measurement type, and each row is an item. It is specialized for doing statistical analysis on these data. A data.frame is in fact a specialized type of list: each column is a list element.
Upvotes:
3
A dataframe has to be rectangular, i.e. the number of rows in each column must be the same. The entries don't have to be of the same type, so one column can be Boolean and another can be character, for example.

A matrix has optional row and column names. [a matrix is fundamentally a vector of length NxM with dimensions dim added. It is filled by columns. Arrays are like higher dimensional matrices. a data.frame is a list of vectors of the same length (they can have different types), with optional names (column names). Note that this makes the columns and rows very different, unlike a matrix. Rows have optional names too. For any multidimensional object X, dimnames(X) gives and sets the names of rows and columns (and higher dimensions in arrays). It consists of a list of character vectors of the appropriate lengths. The list is usually indexed with the names of the elements, or alternatively with integers. A matrix is a two- or more dimensional structure: columns and rows. I think it is mostly used for numerical calculations like in linear algebra, but I think it can also be used for general data storage. A data.frame is also two dimensional, but it is used for statistical data that belongs together, like different measurements of the same items. Each column is a measurement type, and each row is an item. It is specialized for doing statistical analysis on these data. A data.frame is in fact a specialized type of list: each column is a list element.

Arrays are like higher dimensional matrices. a data.frame is a list of vectors of the same length (they can have different types), with optional names (column names). For any multidimensional object X, dimnames(X) gives and sets the names of rows and columns (and higher dimensions in arrays). It consists of a list of character vectors of the appropriate lengths. So for a matrix or dataframe X, dimnames gives a two element list corresponding to rownames(X) and colnames(X).

Input.threadtitle: How is R free software if S is not?
Input.posts:
If R is an implementation of the S programming language, and S is owned by TIBCO, how can R be free software? Doesn't TIBCO have a claim to it?
Upvotes:
0
IANAL but I suspect that the source code that implements S (for example, in C) is protected by TIBCO's copyright. The developers of R can provide the same functionality as S if they start from scratch and write their own compiler/interpreter without copying TIBCO's code base. So for example assume that S had a function called read.csv. TIBCO engineers wrote some code in C that got compiled into a binary that gets executed when someone using S calls that function. That implementation is protected. However, they don't own the string 'read.csv' so someone else can come along and write their own code that gets compiled into a binary that gets executed when someone who hasn't bought S calls the R function read.csv. As an analogy I can write a recipe for how to make banana bread. That recipe is copyrighted, so no one else can publish my explanation for how to make banana bread using my words. However, I can't prevent another person from explaining in their own words how to make banana bread, even if their recipe has the exact same ingredients in the exact proportions.

When you read data from any source, if it fits in your memory -- and that is the case for this small file -- the best thing to avoid reading the file each time you want to do any operation is to store the contents of the file into one variable. For that, you choose a name for your variable, let's say my_variable, and assign the result of reading the file to that variable using the assignation operator '<-'. For example: my_variable <- read.csv('hw_data.csv') will read the contents of the data file, store them into a data frame and then assign the data frame to the variable my_variable. From that point you can use my_variable and forget about the file.
